descriptions.content:
This copula indicates a past or present testimony on the speaker’s part and implies that the speaker is or has been a direct witness to whatever he or she is asserting. In English, it is translated by the same expressions as for ཡོད་རེད་, i.e., according to context as “to be at” (situative sense), “to be” (existential sense), “to have” (possessive sense), or by the verb “to be” (attributive sense). The latter applies only when the verb is preceded by a qualifying adjective. Thus the only difference between འདུག་ and ཡོད་རེད་ lies in the different evidential moods they express (these moods have been described above). The translation of the following phrases would therefore be exactly the same as those given above:

  • བོད་ལ་གནམ་གྲུ་འདུག “There are airplanes in Tibet.”
  • ཐུབ་བསྟན་ལགས་འདའི་(འདིར་)འདུག “Tupten is here.”
  • ཁོང་ལ་དེབ་མང་པོ་འདུག “He has many books.”
  • འདི་སྙིང་རྗེ་པོ་འདུག “This is pretty.”
  • འདི་གསལ་པོ་འདུག “This is clear.”
  • འདི་ཚ་པོ་འདུག “This is hot.”

However, exactly as in the case of the assertive copula, it is impossible to say:

  • · *ཁོང་རྒྱ་མི་མི་འདུག “He is Chinese.”
